adr_address: Via Renzo Bertoni, 3, 20121 Milano MI, Italy

editorial_summary.overview: Monochrome quarters in a bright hostel set in a former monastery, offering free Wi-Fi & a kitchen.

formatted_address: Via Renzo Bertoni, 3, 20121 Milano MI, Italy
name: New Generation Hostel Urban Brera

plus_code.compound_code: F5GR+6W Milan, Metropolitan City of Milan, Italy

reviews.text: The photo here of a beautiful monastery courtyard should be removed.  If this is the building the hostel is on one would never know it.  While I had a super night's sleep and felt safe and the location is great it is not beautiful.  There's absolutely no courtyard, no view of any sort.

This hostel was absolutely miserable.

They provide a single towel for showering to each guest in a room, but do not provide any communal towels for handwashing or as a shower mat.

The hostel only provides a single sheet as a blanket, which is fine because it’s so hot in the rooms i didn’t sleep with anything on me. The advertised AC barely functions and has 0 impact on the temperature of the room, while the screens on the windows are all broken so if you open the window you will wake up covered in mosquito bites.

The mattress is so old that there is a human shaped divot that your body will sink into.

The shower head sprayed water in 3 directions at 3 different pressures. We had to keep it at the lowest height in order for the water to not shoot over the top of the shower door. The shower door also had a terrible seal and was less effective than a regular shower curtain at stopping water from getting all over the bathroom… and once again we did not have any extra towels for the bathroom floor.

The only redeeming factors about this place were the sizable wall lockers and its location.

Well, I’m just glad I only stayed for one night. Easily the worst hostel I’ve ever stayed in...
One of the most frustrating things was having to leave all my keys—including the locker key and room key—at the reception every time I left the hostel. I still don’t understand why this is necessary.
The common area is basically non-existent, and the tiny space that does exist is lit by an intense red light that feels like something straight out of Amsterdam’s Red Light District, not cozy or welcoming at all.
The rooms were not clean. There were no curtains around the beds, and the beds weren’t even properly made. Instead of a duvet cover, they just gave two plain sheets like one for the mattress and one, I suppose, to cover yourself with? The mattress protector looked really dirty and clearly hadn’t been changed.
From the moment you walk in, you’re bombarded with signs that say things like “If you break this, you’ll pay X euros” or “damage that, and it’ll cost Y” I mean, not exactly a warm welcome. And it made me so uncomfortable that I actually took photos of the broken things I found in the room like the bedside lamp, just in case they tried to charge me for it later.
The staff were far from friendly. There was barely any toilet paper in the bathrooms. The elevator felt very unsafe. The flush in my room didn’t work properly. And the hairdryer barely blew any air and gave off a burnt smell, so I couldn’t even use it I mean it was obviously broken.
The only good thing about this place is the location. But honestly, I don’t think it’s worth staying here just for that...

The hostel itself is quite good, they have an elevator, they have plenty of things you can buy like snacks, drinks, etc., yet you had to buy your essentials like soap and towels, which is not good. They have a snooker table, a kitchen and the rooms have good space.

But the main thing that stood out, and that outweighed anything that was good, was the air conditioning. The moment you’d step into the hostel it was so hot, it was unbearable. My room had AC, but the remote didn’t work and it was stuck on 28°C, just blowing off hot air. People asked the reception if there’s was something we could do and they just didn’t even bother doing anything.

Basically, I’d recommend it if you want an accessible and central hostel, but you’ll have to be prepared for the stifling and unpleasant heat.

The hostel was quite okay and there were a lot of things accessible to us, like equipped kitchen and bigger common rooms. Yet what stood out the most was the extreme heat that was felt as soon as you entered the building. The air conditionings weren’t working and in the room i was staying at the ac was stuck at 28°, while the reception told us that was nothing they could do.
I’d still recommend the hostel for the accessibility and location, although this main aspect was a very hard to deal throughout my stay.
